title: How to Make Enchilada Sauce

steps.headline: Melt the butter or margarine in a saucepan on medium heat.
Add the flour.
steps.description: Three tablespoons should be enough but if not, add a little more to form a loose paste.

steps.headline: Add 1 cup of water to the flour.
steps.description: Also add along with the ground chili powder and ground cumin.

steps.headline: Bring to a low boil, just long enough to thicken the sauce.
steps.description: If the sauce seems a bit too thick for your needs, it can be thinned further with more water.

steps.headline: When the sauce is to the taste and of a consistency that you prefer, pour it over the rolled and filled tortillas.
steps.description: It can also be used with any other Mexican dish you like.

steps.headline: Bring a saucepan of water to the boil.
steps.description: Add the garlic cloves and chilies.

steps.headline: Add the tomatillos five minutes later.
steps.description: Cook for another 5 minutes, then remove from the heat and drain.

steps.headline: Place the cooked tomatillos, garlic and chilies into a blender.
steps.description: Add an onion quarter and cilantro (fresh coriander). Blend briefly––the cilantro should be still visible and not ground too finely.

steps.headline: Add the cup of stock.
Pour the purée into a small skillet.
steps.description: Sauté the purée. Add salt to season, according to your taste.

steps.headline: Lower the heat.
steps.description: Leave to cook, uncovered, for 10 minutes. Add more stock if the sauce appears too thick.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Spoon the warm sauce over the rolled and stuffed enchiladas. Cream or queso fresco can be added on top of the sauce if you like.

steps.headline: Add the chopped tomatoes, onion, chilies, garlic, salt, sugar and tomato purée to a blender or food processor.
Melt the butter or margarine in a large skillet.
steps.description: Add the purée to the warm butter and let simmer for 5 minutes. Remove from the heat temporarily.

steps.headline: In a small mixing bowl, beat the eggs and cream together.
Add one spoonful of the warm purée to the egg and cream mixture.
steps.description: Mix quickly to prevent cooking of the eggs.

steps.headline: Pour the egg and cream mixture into the rest of the purée.
Return the purée to a low heat.
steps.description: Slowly heat, stirring constantly. The mixture will gradually thicken. Do not allow to boil.

steps.headline: Divide the sauce.
steps.description: Add a quarter of the sauce to the enchilada filling (such as meat and fried bell pepper) and stir through. Pour the rest of the sauce over the enchiladas after they are arranged in a baking dish, prior to baking the enchiladas. When the sauce bubbles, the dish is ready to serve.

steps.headline: Heat the olive oil in a nonstick skillet until it is shimmering.
Add the flour and cook it for one minute, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon.
Add the chili powder and cook for an additional minute.
Pour in the vegetable stock and tomato paste.
Sprinkle the sauce with cumin and oregano and stir the sauce well to combine all of the ingredients.
Bring the sauce to a simmer.
steps.description: Cook the sauce for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally with a wooden spoon.

steps.headline: Remove the sauce from the heat.
steps.description: Either use it in your recipe or place it into an airtight container to store it.

steps.headline: Finished.

text: Simple enchilada sauce Melt the butter or margarine in a saucepan on medium heat.  Add the flour. Three tablespoons should be enough but if not, add a little more to form a loose paste. Add 1 cup of water to the flour. Also add along with the ground chili powder and ground cumin. Bring to a low boil, just long enough to thicken the sauce. If the sauce seems a bit too thick for your needs, it can be thinned further with more water. When the sauce is to the taste and of a consistency that you prefer, pour it over the rolled and filled tortillas. It can also be used with any other Mexican dish you like. Tomatillo (green tomato) enchilada sauce Bring a saucepan of water to the boil. Add the garlic cloves and chilies. Add the tomatillos five minutes later. Cook for another 5 minutes, then remove from the heat and drain. Place the cooked tomatillos, garlic and chilies into a blender. Add an onion quarter and cilantro (fresh coriander). Blend briefly––the cilantro should be still visible and not ground too finely. Add the cup of stock.  Pour the purée into a small skillet. Sauté the purée. Add salt to season, according to your taste. Lower the heat. Leave to cook, uncovered, for 10 minutes. Add more stock if the sauce appears too thick. Remove from the heat. Spoon the warm sauce over the rolled and stuffed enchiladas. Cream or queso fresco can be added on top of the sauce if you like. Creamy tomato enchilada sauce Add the chopped tomatoes, onion, chilies, garlic, salt, sugar and tomato purée to a blender or food processor. Purée until smooth. Melt the butter or margarine in a large skillet. Add the purée to the warm butter and let simmer for 5 minutes. Remove from the heat temporarily. In a small mixing bowl, beat the eggs and cream together. Mix well. Add one spoonful of the warm purée to the egg and cream mixture. Mix quickly to prevent cooking of the eggs. Pour the egg and cream mixture into the rest of the purée. Mix through. Return the purée to a low heat. Slowly heat, stirring constantly. The mixture will gradually thicken. Do not allow to boil. Divide the sauce. Add a quarter of the sauce to the enchilada filling (such as meat and fried bell pepper) and stir through. Pour the rest of the sauce over the enchiladas after they are arranged in a baking dish, prior to baking the enchiladas. When the sauce bubbles, the dish is ready to serve. Red vegan enchilada sauce Heat the olive oil in a nonstick skillet until it is shimmering.  Add the flour and cook it for one minute, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon.  Add the chili powder and cook for an additional minute.  Pour in the vegetable stock and tomato paste.  Sprinkle the sauce with cumin and oregano and stir the sauce well to combine all of the ingredients.  Bring the sauce to a simmer. Cook the sauce for 15 minutes, stirring occasionally with a wooden spoon. Remove the sauce from the heat. Either use it in your recipe or place it into an airtight container to store it. Finished.
